titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kellogg Family Papers 1755-1890 MS 016 MS 016 MS 016
titlestmt.author: Processed by Guest

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-02-02 07:37:52 -0800.

did.unittitle: Kellogg Family Papers
did.abstract: This collection contains items related to four generations of the Kellogg family of Cornwall.

archdesc.userestrict:
Use Restrictions Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:

7 Pine Street

Cornwall, CT 06753
Phone: 860-672-0505
E-mail: CornHistSoc@optonline.net

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Kellogg Family Papers; MS 016; box number; folder number; Cornwall Historical Society

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: "The Kelloggs were prominent figures in Cornwall’s legal, ecclesiastical, and military life, and intermarried with many other of Cornwall’s leading families. In 1774, Judah Kellogg (1739-1819) moved to Cornwall from Stratford, Connecticut with his wife, Mary Tomlinson Kellogg (1744-1836). Judah Kellogg served as a deacon in the First Church, and as a justice of the peace after 1779. He also represented Cornwall at the state assembly for four years during the American Revolution, from 1776-1779. Judah Kellogg died in Cornwall on April 20, 1819.William Kellogg (1769-1829) was born in Stratford and moved to Cornwall as a young child. William was Judah and Mary’s eldest son, and succeeded his father as town clerk. William married Dennis, a daughter of Heman Swift, and had four sons. He died in Cornwall on May 28, 1829.Frederick Kellogg (1801-1891) was born to William and Dennis Kellogg in Cornwall on September 5, 1801. Frederick was a storeowner and, like his father and grandfather, active in local legal and political matters. On September 16, 1829, he married Ruth Calhoun (1805-1869), daughter of Dr. John Calhoun. Frederick represented Cornwall for four years in the state legislature, and was appointed a judge in 1852. In the early 1840s, he played a key role in getting the Housatonic Railroad constructed. He died in Cornwall on August 14, 1891.Frederick’s older brother Philo Kellogg (1794-1862) was born in Cornwall on March 1, 1794. Like his brother, he also served as a representative and as a judge. He was married to Charlotte Miles and lived on his grandfather Judah’s old farm. He died in Cornwall in 1862.Theodore Kellogg (1824-1903) was born to Philo and Charlotte Kellogg in 1824. Theodore also entered the legal profession and worked as an attorney before being disbarred for “intemperance.” He was well known for his eccentric nature and humor, and was married to Maria C. Sturges (1831-1904)."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection is contained in three archival boxes. The first box of the series contains items relating to specific members of the Kellogg family. Items are organized generationally into sections, and filed chronologically within those sections.

Series II contains general records that are not attributed to any specific member of the Kellogg family. Documents are divided into sections devoted to ecclesiastical, legal, military, property, library, and miscellaneous records, respectively. Within each section, items are organized in chronological order.

Series III is comprised of papers related to families associated with the Kelloggs. It is specifically divided into sections for the Calhoun, Pierce, and Stone families. Items within those sections are filed in chronological order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by subject/author heading then chronologically within each subject/author heading.
The files are grouped into 3 series:

list.item: Calhoun, Pierce, and Stone Family Papers
